Award.AwardTitle: An Asset Model Approach for Building Capacity in a Rural Region for the Recruitment, Mentoring, and Licensing of Math and Science Preservice Teachers
Award.AbstractNarration: The project aims to serve the national need of producing high quality STEM math and science teachers. This project intends to build capacity to create a pathway from high school to science or mathematics teacher certification with a focus on students in rural locales. This project will serve national interest and the Noyce program’s intent through implementing an asset-based approach that builds upon the strengths of a rural community in the recruitment and mentoring of students to fill much needed positions in STEM teaching. Significant to this project is the identification of how the unique strengths of a rural region can be leveraged to create a pathway for students from high school to STEM teacher licensure. This is important because rural regions across the nation are struggling with recruiting and retaining high quality STEM teachers. This project proposes to both capitalize on the strengths of the local community and to implement a series of steps towards the creation of a pathway to recruit, mentor, and prepare STEM students for teacher certification. This includes working with the local community, the newly aligned two-year college branch campuses that tend to serve primarily low-income students, and high school students’ own enthusiasm for mathematics and science. This project has the potential to provide useful information on a different, more direct approach for recruiting students along with how to create a pathway from high school to STEM teacher certification to address the need for more high-quality science and mathematics teachers. <br/><br/>This Capacity Building project at the University of Wisconsin-Platteville, a comprehensive public institution, is in partnership with its two 2-year branch campuses, UW-Platteville Baraboo Sauk County and UW-Platteville Richmond. The project’s overarching goal is to create a “grow-your-own” program, designed to recruit promising high school seniors, and to then provide innovative, continual support as they travel on the path to becoming highly-qualified high school STEM educators. The project will achieve this by building partnerships, creating a cohort-centered mentoring program, and systematically gathering and analyzing data. The project’s intellectual merit includes the use of an asset model approach to leverage the strengths of a rural community in the recruiting and supporting of STEM students seeking education licensing. The project’s broader impacts will provide other institutions, particularly those in a dynamic post-secondary state system, the steps necessary for creating a pathway that eases rural students’ transition from high school, to a two-year institution, to a four-year institution, then to the classroom as high-quality, licensed science or mathematics teachers. The work will be evaluated by examining the effectiveness of the proposed Capacity Building approach that leads to the creation and submission of a future Noyce proposal. The findings will be disseminated through established regional and national networks focused on improving science and mathematics K-12 teachers. This Capacity Building project is supported through the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program (Noyce). The Noyce program supports talented STEM undergraduate majors and professionals to become effective K-12 STEM teachers and experienced, exemplary K-12 teachers to become STEM master teachers in high-need school districts. It also supports research on the persistence, retention, and effectiveness of K-12 STEM teachers in high-need school districts.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project, An Asset Model Approach for Building Capacity in a Rural Region for Recruitment, Mentoring, and Licensing of Math and Science Preservice Teachers, successfully completed its goals. The project began in June of 2021 and was completed in June of 2022. A ?grow your own? program, the project was designed to recruit promising high school seniors and provide mentoring connections for those students as they begin the path to become high school STEM educators.

The proposal involved secondary education STEM instructors from the tri-state region of northeast Iowa, northwest Illinois, and southwest Wisconsin. Hundreds of teachers were invited to be involved in the project. Many of those teachers provided project support. Twenty-six teachers were actively involved in the project. They served as student recruiters and mentors. The actively involved teaches identified qualified ?students of promise,? students who were interested in STEM fields and who had aptitudes for becoming potential teachers. Twenty-four students were directly contacted. Those students were encouraged and advised regarding the advantages of STEM teaching. The students also had the opportunity to enroll in dual-credit education courses that offer both high school and college credit. They all were invited to a celebration of teaching at the end of the 2021-2022 academic year.

The home institution of the project is situated in a rural area. The focus of the project remained on this tristate region. Research indicates that ?regional institutions in rural areas, which attract local students, are well situated for rural teacher preparation programs?. Many rural students intend to return to their home communities to teach upon graduation.

Six objectives were addressed in the course of the project. Objective 1, Engage: to enlist the assistance of STEM in-service teachers to recruit motivated and engaged high school STEM students to enter the field of education; a goal for the first year will be enlistment of ten students from the tri-state area. Objective 2, Encourage: to form a cohort of involved STEM mentor teachers and identified STEM-interested students to work together to design evidence-based student progress plans, to support students in presently offered dual-credit programs, and to help prepare the students for matriculation to the university. Objective 3, Establish: to build partnerships among represented school districts, the three University of Wisconsin-Platteville institutions, university departments and personnel, Cooperative Educational Service Agency (CESA) #3, and interested community entities such as area STEM-focused businesses and facilities. Objective 4, Enumerate: to collect, analyze, and synthesize data regarding felt educator needs, working especially with a rural education focus, to inform future efforts. Objective 5, Evaluate:: to develop assessment and value-added plans for each component of the Capacity Building program to ensure student progress and success. Objective 6, Empower: to design a Noyce Scholarship Program (E?s-ing the Path to Becoming a STEM Educator) that capitalizes on established bases, coordinated efforts, identified needs, and the future goal of placing qualified STEM educators in high-needs rural Local Education Agencies (LEAs).

The ultimate outcome was to build an infrastructure within the high schools in the tri-state region that communicates to high school students the value and importance of entering the field of STEM education. To aide in this endeavor, a logo for the project was established, a website launched, a brochure created and a teacher-created ?Why I Teach STEM? video was developed.

The working partners of the project included individuals from University of Wisconsin-Platteville, UW Platteville-Baraboo, and UW-Platteville-Richland Center campuses. The project worked with STEM-major interested high school students and STEM teachers. The teachers gained mentoring skills as they worked with motivated and engaged high school students. As the project progressed over the year, enthusiasm and knowledge of the program traveled in the tristate region of Wisconsin, Iowa, and Illinois. Partnerships and connections among the three university schools and tristate area school districts enriched the broader area. Information on the merits, advantages, and personal satisfaction of STEM teaching was shared in the area. The proposal was built on the premise that high school teachers have a strong, positive influence on their students. Leveraging this influence provided human resources to the tri-state area in dire need of STEM educators. The strength of the project is that it will provide continual support to students as they progress on their way to becoming STEM teachers. Students who are entering post-secondary institutions have mentors in the field that they have worked with in the high school years and are, consequently, comfortable contacting them. The project formalized this connection. The connections built are sustainable and generalizable.
